thread.title: Kenya: Kenyan Teachers Squeeze State

title: Kenya: Kenyan Teachers Squeeze State
text:
Nigeria: Kano Loses N18.1 Million Monthly to "Ghost" Street Cleaners editorial 
The last week has been one of drama in the saga that is the school strike in Kenya. 
The government ordered all schools to be closed after failing to accede to a court ruling, requiring the state to offer the teachers a 60 per cent pay increment. 
Kenya President Uhuru Kenyatta argued that the state could not afford the pay increment, insisting, like his counterparts in Uganda, that this would have to come in the subsequent fiscal year. 
For effect, Kenyatta argued that the state was already spending KSh 568bn of the KSh 1.1trillion collected in revenue (or 52 per cent of its budget) on civil servants' pay, and could not afford to suffocate any more state projects. The teachers are demanding for KShs 16bn in increased pay. 
At this stage, many were ready to negotiate, until he stated that Kenyan teachers were better paid than their regional counterparts; indeed, the third highest paid in Africa after Morocco and South Africa. According to the Kenyan president, the country's lowest paid teachers are taking home KShs 23,000 (about UShs 828,000) per month. 
While Kenyatta left the door open for further negotiations to end the crisis, the opposition seized the moment to make further inroads into an already charged environment, with one eye on the next election. 
Both the Orange Democratic Movement party leader Raila Odinga and Wiper Democratic Party's Kalonzo Musyoka called a major rally at Uhuru Park, where they lambasted the government for its callous attitude to the whole problem, before establishing a 'Teachers Solidarity Account'. 
At the rally, Odinga and Musyoka each donated KSh100,000 (about Shs 3.6m) each to the account. The Opposition leaders also unveiled an M-Pesa account (mobile money facility) through which the public can donate money to the 'Teachers Solidarity Account' in solidarity with teachers. 
Another of the opposition parties, Coalition for Reforms and Democracy (Cord) have vowed to rally their supporters to block Harambee Avenue, where the presidency has its offices, every Tuesday until teachers' pay demands are met. 
The opposition leaders are also planning a parliamentary motion to impeach Kenyatta, although analysts argue that they lack the numbers in the House to upset the president. 
However, with such significant support from state organs as the Teachers' Service Commission (TSC) and parliament, some Kenyan teachers must not be shocked that the government is in a corner. 
After all the drama surrounding the strike, deputy president William Ruto was left to appeal to the TSC and teachers to work out a way to end the strike and allow children to return to school, with crucial end-of-year exams, due in a few weeks from now. At this rate, Kenyatta must envy his counterparts in Uganda, who have teachers under the thumb, despite repeated calls for a pay rise. Kenya
